text: miriam
the believer hi everyone anthony fantano
here internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new lp
blood donation from miriam the believer
you and me both mary
i wish
you would
bleed to death
miriam the believer or miriam wallington
is a singer-songwriter guitarist star
vocalist and one half of the eccentric
swedish musical duo wild birds and peace
drums a project that she's been in for
quite a while now with her husband
andreas berlin wild birds and piece
drums have put out a handful of lps and
eps since they started putting out
studio material in 2007. a lot of the
tracks on the release is being sort of
stripped back instrumentally featuring
for the most part andreas's drums as
well as miriam's vocals which i
understand sort of sounds boring on
paper but the thing is these two are
actually really really skilled musicians
with enough chops to keep these
instrumentally stripped back songs
really interesting miriam and her
husband play with with quite a bit of
intensity on some of these wild birds
and piece drum songs and even though
that is sort of a thrill to hear a
thrill to experience it doesn't really
add up much into sort of traditional
coherent
songwriting mostly because that's not
what they're going for a lot of the time
even as they they work to incorporate
more musical instrumentation and layers
into their subsequent albums this new
record of merriam's though is a move
toward the accessible maybe not a pop
album sometimes an art pop album but
overall just much smoother in terms of
delivering accessible melodies and and
just straightforward chord progressions
miriam's vocals are are still rife with
with personality and some really bold
vocalizations and her husband's drumming
is on this album as well but both of
them feel relatively reserved in
comparison to the wild birds and piece
drums material probably in an effort to
deliver some songs that are easier on
the ears and allow the other
instrumentation the guitar the
synthesizers the bass to make it into
the mix and sort of effectively play the
roles that they have to play yes miriam
and her husband are sounding less
bombastic but i'm still catching a lot
of the stylistic influences that that
you would catch on a wild birds project
the soul music is here the jazz the rock
but it's all sort of delivered with this
more easy going slightly eerie and in
dark tinge rather than wild and free
miriam comes off feeling very alluring
and moody on these tracks miriam's
vocals and the rest of the
instrumentation are recorded and and
produced to sound a little cavernous
reverby kind of distant but still there
there's an intimacy there on these
tracks and everything comes in really
clear especially miriam's vocals and
there are moments where miriam's voice
sort of reminds me of the vocals of
other artists maybe victoria legrand
from beach house on the track the string
of everything one of the slower more
dream pop influence tracks on this album
really jangly shimmering guitars on this
song and miriam seems to be reaching
into these just low
bellowing notes that remind me of
victoria's singing but of course
throughout this track and many others
marion proves herself to be much more of
a nimble vocalist when she reaches into
her upper register i hear slight flashes
of kate bush there are moments where the
the very mysterious vibe of this album
remind me of chelsea wolf's last
full-length lp but
miriam's volume her very commanding
cadence and her jazzy phrasing with her
vocals really sort of put her on a
pedestal of her own now as far as the
songwriting goes on this lp it is varied
it's memorable and it's emotionally
moving in about every direction miriam
tries to go in the opening track on here
blood donation shimmering guitars
marching drums and a na na na chorus
serve as a really theatrical backdrop
for miriam's fantastic vocal improvs
that track and others on here have some
really smooth easy transitions between
the verses and the choruses like the
song the string of everything or the
track first haiku one of the longer
songs on here in a beautifully
moving ballad really sweet slow pace and
melody on this track and a wonderfully
gorgeous
sac solo to finish it all off there are
several interlude tracks on this lp as
well and on the flip side of these more
easy going songs there are tracks that
are still accessible but seem to work
more in phases songs like dead meat
which slows down speeds up changes
groove over the course of shifting from
averse to a chorus and what also feels
like a second chorus we have one chorus
where miriam is just reaching at the top
of her vocal range and and shouting dead
end the other phase is is more toned
down but just as moving where miriam is
saying that everything she knows and
feels is stuck in spiderweb i love the
chord progression on this track too and
the song invisible giving the longest
track on this lp is maybe the most
multi-phased on the entire lp it is a
dark epic which kicks off with this
incredibly fast and rhythmic drumming
and guitar strumming the beginning also
starts off with this murky bass line and
with all this sort of subtle
instrumentation miriam's voice is like
this huge lightning bolt crashing down
in the middle smack dab in the middle of
the black black skyline and it's this
boldness and it's this contrast that
makes the song so engaging from
beginning to end as it's changing from
one idea to the next now for the wild
birds and piece drums fan there are a
few tracks on here that do sort of
harken back to that stuff but do
also blend into the track list of this
album pretty nicely songs like somewhere
else where miriam is singing lead but
also doing her background vocals if you
can call them that it's like she's
recorded her lead vocals then recorded
these just high-pitched howls and shouts
with this sort of low-fi fuzzy
clipping recording and it's like these
vocals are placed or even sampled and
just sort of played throughout the track
as she's singing against them i'm loving
the hard fast flamenco style groove on
this track too as well as the swirling
synth arpeggios and the song above the
world has one of the kookiest sort of
percussion sections on this entire album
something i could totally see in the
background of a wild bird song now there
are a few downsides on this i mean for
one the interlude songs don't exactly
wow me but they don't exactly tease me
either making me feel like oh this
needed to be longer and there are a few
songs that i wish were a little more
eventful like the track to belong or to
let go one of the jazzier songs on the
album with its groove and its bass line
which are very slow very smoky miriam's
vocalizations over the track are pretty
the song does meet an abrupt end but
still it's it's not like it really
reaches a climax over the course of the
song and the closer is somewhat
anticlimactic as well even though miriam
does do well on some of these more
linear flowing songs these just for me
are not two of the best still on this
record i gotta say overall
miriam has essentially proven herself to
be a really captivating worthwhile and
capable songwriter and on top of that
what what has already been known about
her from previous musical efforts is
that she's a fantastic singer with a
voice that has a ton of personality as
well as melodic sensibility and
emotion considering how exuberant wild
birds and peace drums records are it's
not surprising that blood donation is
exuberant as well just in a slightly
darker way i'm feeling a decent strong
eight on this album if you've given it a
listen what did you think of it did you
love it hate it why what do you think i
should review next and that's it this
review has been my opinion if you don't
like it here is a straw i want to give a
shout out to man man good luck with your
new single and your new album grand
theft auto 5. i love that gameplay
trailer jeremy he's awesome and the
connecticut state judicial system please
allow me to shift my jury duty dates far
into the future so that it does not
interrupt a few things that i've got
going on right now
please only the strong subscribe all
mistakes were intentional anthony
fantano marion the believer
forever
